properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds this afternoon and early evening. Strong west to northwesterly winds gusting up to 80 km/h will develop this afternoon. The strong winds will diminish this evening. The strong winds may throw loose objects, cause tree branches to break and damage property. Power outages are also possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-02T07:28:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-01T15:29:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0550284227.2021

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Periods of heavy snow are expected during the next few hours. Visibilities will be rapidly reduced due to intense snow, moderate winds and blowing snow. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Snow squall warnings are issued when brief but intense bursts of heavy snow will produce near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-01T23:59:03-00:00

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for today. Lake effect snow bands and strong northwesterly winds are expected to produce near zero visibilities at times this afternoon and in the early evening. Local snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are possible by the time snow squall activity weakens this evening. Motorists should prepare for adverse winter driving conditions and adjust their travel plans accordingly. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-02T05:06:03-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winds of up to 90 kilometres per hour are occurring along the shore until this afternoon. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow, strong winds, and blowing snow expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 25 cm, except 5 to 10 cm along parts of the coast. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h, except up to 120 in areas prone to enhanced southeasterlies. Locations: western Newfoundland. Time span: this evening until Tuesday afternoon. Remarks: Local enhancement in southeasterly flow typically occurs in the vicinities of Cape St. George, Port au Port Bay, the outer Bay of Islands, Bonne Bay, Western Brook Pond and St. Pauls Bay. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-02T06:15:52-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds today. Winds have strengthened this morning. Expect strong winds particularly along the shorelines of Whitefish Bay, North Channel and Manitoulin Island. Gusts up to 80 km/h can be expected from late morning into early afternoon. Winds will diminish by evening. Strong winds can throw loose objects, cause tree branches to break, and damage property. Power outages are also possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-02T08:10:17-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall likely mid-week. Locations: the Labrador Coast from Nain to Black Tickle. Time span: Wednesday afternoon into Thursday morning. Remarks: A winter storm is expected to affect the Labrador Coast mid-week. While it is too soon to provide specific details, the potential exists for strong winds accompanied by significant amounts of snow. Additional information will be provided as the details become more certain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-02T06:31:43-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An extended period of snowfall is expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 30 cm (heaviest over higher terrain). Locations: Upper Lake Melville and Eagle River areas. Time span: this evening until Wednesday morning. Maximum wind gusts: easterly 60 km/h over exposed areas. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin this evening and will become heavy, at times, Tuesday morning. Reduced visibility in blowing snow is possible over exposed areas on Tuesday as winds increase from the east. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-02T06:33:06-00:00

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls and dangerous whiteout conditions today and tonight. What: Whiteouts due to blowing snow. Total snow amounts of 15 to 25 cm locally; 5 to 10 cm today, 10 to 15 cm tonight. Where: Blowing snow will be most hazardous in open areas, such as along open fields. When: Now through tonight. The worst period of blowing snow is expected this afternoon until midnight. The most persistent heavier snow is expected this evening. Discussion: Snow squalls will continue through tonight off Lake Huron and Georgian Bay. Widespread blowing snow with possible blizzard-like conditions is the biggest concern this afternoon and evening. Some areas may see heavy snowfall accumulation as well. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-02T06:51:20-00:00

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls and dangerous whiteout conditions today and tonight. What: Whiteouts due to blowing snow. Total snow amounts of 20 to 35 cm locally; 15 cm today, 15 to 25 cm tonight. Wind gusts to 80 km/h. Where: Blowing snow will be most hazardous in open areas, such as along open fields. The heaviest snowfall accumulation is expected in an area that includes Kincardine, Ripley, Lucknow, Wingham, and Gorrie. When: Now through tonight. The worst period of blowing snow is expected this afternoon until midnight. The period of heaviest snowfall is expected this evening. Discussion: Snow squalls will continue through tonight off Lake Huron. Widespread blowing snow with possible blizzard-like conditions is the biggest concern this afternoon and evening. Some areas may see heavy snowfall accumulation as well. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-02T06:55:22-00:00

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blowing snow is expected this afternoon and evening. What: Poor visibility due to blowing snow. Where: Blowing snow will be most hazardous in open areas, such as along open fields. When: This afternoon and this evening. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A vigorous cold front will sweep across the province during the day into this evening and may generate snowsqualls as it passes. Periods of heavy snow are possible with the snow squalls, and visibilities may be greatly reduced under the intense snow. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for brief but intense bursts of heavy snow producing near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-02T03:59:48-00:00

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions are expected on Tuesday. By Tuesday, between 20 and 40 centimetres of snow, along with strong winds and blowing snow, are expected. Beginning overnight tonight through Tuesday morning, intense wind chill values will cause temperatures to feel like near minus 30. Tuesday, westerly winds will intensify and cause widespread blowing snow and visibilities reduced to zero. Wind gusts will reach up to 110 km/h over the northern shore of the Gaspé peninsula. Consider modifying any non-essential travel plans. ### Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-02T06:16:53-00:00

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 30 cm. Maximum wind gusts: easterly 80 to 120 km/h with higher gusts in the Wreckhouse area. Locations: Codroy Valley eastward to the Francois area. Time span: this evening until Tuesday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-02T06:15:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-01T14:16:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2800745315.2021
Area: Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Flash Freeze Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: This evening, the arrival of an Arctic air mass will cause temperatures to drop dramatically, going from plus 2 degrees Celsius to minus 12 degrees Celsius in a few hours. Cold wind chills values near minus 30 are expected. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-02T02:04:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-01T17:05:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3462198131.2021

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of extremely cold wind chills between minus 55 and minus 60 continues. Extreme cold conditions will last through much of the coming week. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-02T08:53:58-00:00

Area: Taloyoak, Gjoa Haven, Kugaaruk

properties.Summary:
Description: Flash freeze conditions have ended. ###

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, strong winds and blowing snow expected Tuesday. Locations: northeastern Newfoundland and the northern Avalon Peninsula. Total snowfall: possibly exceeding 10 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 80 to 100 km/h or higher. Time span: Tuesday. Remarks: Snow is expected to spread across Newfoundland on Tuesday, in combination with strong southeasterly winds and blowing snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-02T06:16:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-01T14:17:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2103713981.2021

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong northwesterly winds today. Winds have eased from their peak last night. However, winds will strengthen again this morning, particularly along the shoreline of Lake Huron. Gusts up to 80 km/h can be expected from late morning through early afternoon. Winds will slowly ease later this afternoon into this evening. Strong winds can throw loose objects, cause tree branches to break, and damage property. Power outages are also possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-02T06:36:49-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-01T14:37:49-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1757880608.2021
Area: Wingham - Blyth - Northern Huron County, Goderich - Bluewater - Southern Huron County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very strong wind gusts are expected or occurring Maximum gusts: southeasterly up to 140 km/h in the Wreckhouse area. Time span: this evening until Tuesday morning. Remarks: Southeasterly winds gusting to 100 km/h will develop this evening then increase to 140 km/h overnight. Winds will ease upon shifting to strong southwesterly Tuesday morning. ### Drivers may lose control of their vehicles; tall vehicles are at risk of being overturned. Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-02T06:15:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-01T14:16:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1990187242.2021
Area: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity

properties.Title: Les Suêtes Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very strong wind gusts that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum Les Suetes gusts: 130 km/h. Time span: this afternoon until late this evening. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may result in power outages and fallen tree branches. Les Suêtes wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-02T06:35:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-01T14:36:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2481073159.2021
Area: Inverness County - Mabou and north

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum wind gusts: 90 km/h. Locations: Iles de la Madeleine. Time span: Tuesday afternoon and Tuesday night. Remarks: Strong west to northwest winds gusting to 90 km/h will develop near noon on Tuesday and persist through to overnight Tuesday. These strong winds may cause blowing snow over exposed areas giving reduced visibilities. ### Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls and dangerous whiteout conditions today and tonight. What: Whiteouts due to blowing snow. Total snow amounts of 20 to 35 cm locally; 15 cm today, 15 to 25 cm tonight. Wind gusts to 80 km/h. Where: Blowing snow will be most hazardous in open areas, such as along open fields. The heaviest snowfall accumulation is expected in an area that includes Kincardine, Ripley, Lucknow, Wingham, and Gorrie. When: Now through tonight. The worst period of blowing snow is expected this afternoon until midnight. The period of heaviest snowfall is expected this evening. Discussion: Snow squalls will continue through tonight off Lake Huron. Widespread blowing snow with possible blizzard-like conditions is the biggest concern this afternoon and evening. Some areas may see heavy snowfall accumulation as well. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-02T06:36:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-01T14:37:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1338309754.2021
Area: Saugeen Shores - Kincardine - Southern Bruce County, Wingham - Blyth - Northern Huron County, Listowel - Milverton - Northern Perth County, Goderich - Bluewater - Southern Huron County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Extremely cold wind chill values near minus 45 continue. Wind chills will improve later this morning as temperatures continue to increase. ### Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 30 to 40 cm (heaviest inland and over higher terrain). Maximum wind gusts: easterly 80 km/h. Locations: the Labrador Straits. Time span: overnight tonight until near midnight Tuesday night. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin overnight tonight and become heavy, at times, Tuesday morning. Gusty easterly winds combined with the fresh snowfall will cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow during the day on Tuesday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-03-02T06:32:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-01T14:33:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0357743947.2021
Area: Red Bay to L'Anse-au-Clair
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Higher than normal water levels with large waves are expected near the coast. Warning of potential breaking sea conditions and overwash issued jointly by Fisheries and Oceans Canada (Science) and the Meteorological Service of Canada - Quebec Region on 2021-03-01. An intense low pressure system from New England will give strong winds over the regions listed below. The combination of these winds and the fact that we are currently in a period of high tidal range may produce minor breaking sea conditions along the coast near these localities, on the dates and at the times specified (Eastern Standard Time): Sept-Îles - Port-Cartier: 2021-03-01, from 01:30 PM to 04:30 PM. ### Coastal flooding is possible along the shoreline. Storm surge warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-02T01:59:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-01T17:06:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3040004536.2021
Area: Baie-Trinité area, Sept-Îles - Port-Cartier area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. High wind gusts, up to 90 km/h, will continue in wind prone areas today. Winds will weaken this evening. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-02T04:59:14-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Snowfall amounts of 30 to 50 centimetres as well as strong winds and blowing snow are expected until Tuesday. Snow at times heavy will begin this morning. During the day, winds up to 80 kilometres per hour will reduce visibilities to nil in widespread blowing snow. High winds could reach up to 110 kilometres per hour in the Blanc-Sablon area and give zero visibilities in blowing snow beginning early Tuesday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-02T06:18:35-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum wind gusts: 90 km/h. Locations: northeastern New Brunswick. Time span: Tuesday and Tuesday night. Remarks: Strong west to northwest winds gusting to 90 km/h along parts of the Chaleur coast will develop early Tuesday morning and persist through Tuesday night. Winds are expected to drop below warning criteria by Wednesday morning. These strong winds will cause blowing snow over exposed areas giving reduced visibilities, especially over the Acadian Peninsula. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-02T06:36:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-01T14:37:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2077880673.2021
Area: Campbellton and eastern half of Restigouche County, Bathurst and Chaleur Region, Acadian Peninsula
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Time span: today and tonight. Locations: Prince county PEI Remarks: Snow, heavy at times, will spread across the Island today. Snow will mix with or change to rain over southern parts of Prince county for a time this evening which will reduce snow accumulations there. Snow or rain will then taper to flurries overnight tonight with strong and gusty northwest winds developing which will usher in very cold temperatures and cold windchills on Tuesday. Some blowing snow is possible on Tuesday especially over exposed areas. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-02T06:37:48-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-01T14:38:48-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0767198917.2021
Area: Prince County P.E.I.
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Time span: late this afternoon until overnight tonight. Locations: Iles de la Madeleine. Remarks: Snow, heavy at times, will develop over the islands beginning late this afternoon and will briefly change over to a few rain showers overnight tonight then to a few flurries early Tuesday morning. Very strong westerly winds and rapidly falling temperatures will develop early Tuesday morning behind the storm. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Light to moderate north winds combined with temperatures near minus forty are resulting in wind chill values of -55 or lower late this morning. Wind chill values will moderate slightly this afternoon however extreme wind chill values are expected to return to the area tonight into Tuesday morning. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Maximum wind gusts: 70 to 90 km/h. Locations: areas along the Bay of Chaleur coast. Time span: early Tuesday morning into Wednesday morning. Remarks: Fresh snowfall today and tonight will combine with strengthening northwesterly winds overnight and Tuesday to produce poor visibility in blowing snow. Conditions are expected to gradually improve on Wednesday. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-02T06:38:49-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Time span: today and tonight. Locations: central and northern New Brunswick Remarks: Snow, heavy at times, will spread eastward across central and northern New Brunswick today. Snow will mix with rain in some areas this afternoon. Snow will taper to flurries overnight tonight with strong and gusty northwest winds developing which will usher in very cold temperatures and cold windchills on Tuesday. Some blowing snow is possible on Tuesday especially over exposed areas. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
